awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mathematics of Doing, Understanding, Learning and Educating for Secondary Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
Preparing students to make contributions in the fields of science, statistics, mathematics, and technology is critical for our country to remain a world leader.  To accomplish this, it is important for our middle and high school mathematics teachers to be well prepared for teaching mathematics. The Mathematics of Doing, Understanding, Learning and Educating for Secondary Schools (MODULE(S2)) project will create course materials that will be used to develop preservice teachers' mathematical knowledge as it relates specifically to the work of teaching geometry, statistics, algebra, and modeling. These modules will be used in university mathematics courses and piloted with faculty at universities and colleges of all types across the United States. The project will promote effective instruction by offering professional development activities for faculty using the modules during the summers and the school year. Additionally, the project will investigate the impact of instruction with the modules on preservice teachers' knowledge and inform nationwide efforts in teacher education. This five year project will build on efforts by the Mathematics Teacher Education Partnership (MTE-P) to create a gold standard for the preparation of secondary mathematics teachers across its 90 member universities.

Evidence has mounted in recent decades that to implement sound mathematics instruction, teachers must possess understandings of content that are specifically applied in the work of teaching (mathematical knowledge for teaching - MKT). To develop MKT, preservice teachers need opportunities to use mathematical knowledge to recognize, respond to, and understand mathematical issues that arise in the context of teaching. Findings from small pilots with initial geometry and statistics modules developed by the project indicate an increase in preservice secondary teachers' MKT. MODULE(S2) will expand these materials and examine the conditions of instruction that impact preservice teachers' MKT, development of MKT, and expectancy and value in using MKT as a resource for teaching. The project will use mixed methods to provide empirically-based accounts of how factors of quality of instruction and of instructional resources impact preservice teachers' MKT. In addition, results will be used multiple times per year to improve the MODULE(S2) materials through improvement cycles carried out as a part of the Networked Improvement Community design. The Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program is providing co-funding for this project in recognition of its alignment with the broader teacher preparation goals of the Noyce effort.

por.por_cntn:
For decades, secondary mathematics teachers (grades 7-12) have expressed frustration with the university level math courses they take. They reported a disconnect between the mathematics emphasized and the mathematics they will teach, and they felt the teaching strategies they experienced did not prepare them well to teach secondary students. The Mathematics Of Doing, Understanding, Learning and Educating for Secondary Schools (MODULE(S2)) Project addressed these problems by creating (1) curriculum materials for university mathematics and statistics courses that directly connect advanced university-level content to teaching secondary math and statistics and (2) teaching resources for university faculty. MODULE(S2) materials are substantial and freely available. They can be the textbook for semester-long courses in four different content areas: Algebra, Geometry, Statistics, and Modeling. Each area is split into three self-contained modules that can be mixed and matched across content areas for use in capstone or special topics courses that future secondary math teachers take. MODULE(S2) materials also support faculty and future teachers to use teaching practices focused on student thinking—practices that help teachers determine how students understand ideas and then ask questions and have discussions that move students’ thinking toward deeper understanding. 

The MODULE(S2) project was NSF funded for six years and involved faculty at over 150 universities and community colleges. Fifty-eight faculty at 53 universities piloted the MODULE(S2) curriculum materials over the first four project years. Faculty received intensive training and support to use the materials—both in the summer prior to using the materials and throughout the academic year. In the final project year, 100+ institutions requested access to MODULE(S2) curriculum materials and training resources. 

 

Key Findings

MODULE(S2) supports increased knowledge for teaching math and statistics: While using MODULE(S2) materials, 75% of future secondary teachers increased their knowledge for teaching math and statistics. Increases occurred after learning in courses using MODULE(S2) with an instructor that completed MODULE(S2) training. 

MODULE(S2) supports increased confidence to focus teaching on student thinking: Future secondary teachers do not always experience learning math and statistics in settings that focus on their thinking (as students). After using MODULE(S2) curriculum materials, future math and statistics teachers showed significant increases across the board in their confidence to focus their future instruction on student thinking. 

Simulations of teaching support future teachers: MODULE(S2) curriculum materials describe hypothetical teaching situations that ask future teachers to build on student thinking in their responses to students. Results showed that responses were topic dependent—the quality of one simulation response did not predict the quality of another simulation response later in the semester. This suggests that future teachers should have practice teaching opportunities for many topics within a single course.

Contexts that explore justice and equitable social outcomes can provide meaningful learning opportunities in statistics and modeling lessons: After learning statistics using MODULE(S2) materials, future teachers showed an increase in their value of and likelihood of using their equity literacy and critical statistical literacy when teaching. Evidence showed that the modeling and statistics materials, which have sustained attention to social justice and equity issues alongside content development, impact future teachers’ attitudes toward teaching mathematics for social justice and equity. 

Faculty need opportunities to develop their own knowledge for teaching math and statistics: During MODULE(S2) training sessions, instructors developed their skills at attending to and centering future teachers’ thinking in their teaching. However, they focused more on the math and statistics content than the future teachers’ thinking when they felt uncertainty about their teaching strategies. 

 

Research Process

The MODULE(S2) project used a three-pronged approach: First, we developed research-based curriculum materials; second, we recruited and trained faculty to use the materials; and third, we conducted research to investigate and develop theory and insights into how future teachers learn mathematics and statistics in ways that can inform their future teaching. 

Two questions guided the MODULE(S2) Project research: (1) What changes occur in the instruction of faculty who participate in MODULE(S2) professional development during the term that they use the materials? and (2) What changes occur in future secondary mathematics and statistics teachers’ knowledge for teaching math during the term that they use the materials? We collected classroom video, interview, and survey data from over 50 faculty members. Additionally, we collected survey data and simulation of teaching assignments from 400+ future teachers. These data were analyzed to better understand how future teachers develop knowledge for teaching secondary math and statistics when taking university courses. 

The MODULE(S2) Project produced high-quality curriculum materials (available for distribution at no cost) for four university-level mathematics and statistics courses. Our research theorized how future teachers develop knowledge for teaching mathematics and statistics at secondary levels. The MODULE(S2) project’s findings have been disseminated in over 85 presentations and workshops and 28 peer-reviewed book chapters, journal articles, and conference proceedings. Find more MODULE(S2) Project information at www.modules2.com
